column6:
(Organisation and Management of Regulation (3H070705)
Promotor :
  • person Verhoest Koen (+) - Public Governance Institute (+)
Duration :
01/10/2007 - 25/06/2012
Doctorandus :
Rommel Jan - Doctoral Programme in Social Sciences (Leuven) - Faculty of Social Sciences
PhD defence date :

25/06/2012

PhD defence file :
http://www.kuleuven.be/doctoraatsverdediging/fiches/3H07/3H070705.htm
Phd Full text :
https://lirias.kuleuven.be/handle/123456789/349740
Project summary :
Regulation is an important task for governments and is frequently used to steer both economic and social activities. In recent years, the literature has described the rise of the ‘regulatory state’, which uses a particular set of instruments (e.g. licensing, inspections) to regulate private actors. The tasks are often allocated to newly created organisations that are placed at arm’s length of the minister (e.g. sectoral regulators in liberalized sectors such as energy, telecommunications, post). Such proliferation of the number of regulators has been said to lead to fragmentation, so that a single organisation no longer has full authority over a particular sector. Instead, sectors are regulated by entire ‘institutional constellations’:\xa0 networks of regulators in different sectors, on different governmental levels and with different regulatory mandates. Each of these bodies has at best a partial authority over a sector. This doctoral research aims two answer two research questions. First,how do these institutional constellations look like? To answer this question, a mapping of regulatory bodies is performed to shed a light on the core characteristics of regulators (e.g. amount of autonomy, extent offragmentation, tasks,…). The second research question is: what is the effect of such constellations on individual regulators? By performing comparative case studies the research explores whether the proliferation and fragmentation may hollow out the factual autonomy of regulators.\xa0
Discipline(s) :
  • Sociology of labour, sociology of enterprise
column9:
(Re-)Organising the state's monopoly on violence: research on the organization, effectiveness and efficiency of the police force by means of an 'overall design'. (3H050458)
Promotor :
  • person Van Hootegem Geert (+) - Centre for Sociological Research (+)
Duration :
01/10/2005 - 30/09/2010
Doctorandus :
Van Beek Gert - Doctoral Programme in Social Sciences (Leuven) - Faculty of Social Sciences
Project summary :
In their observations and descriptions of modern society, contemporary sociologists consistently stress the importance of a number of political, economic, cultural, technological and ideological changes taking placein the context of\xa0'modernity'. Some scholars have characterised this modern society as a\xa0'world risk society' which is dominated by attempts to manage and control\xa0'new' risks, stemming (as side-effects) from modernity itself. One of these risk relates to the problem of (un) safety and (in)security, which can be framed and (partially) explained in the context of the risk society. Some\xa0scholars have consideredcriminality and fear of crime as a specific (social-political) risk forwhich citizens hold the official authorities accountable. In an attemptto manage and minimize this safety risk, modern nation states have designed formal organisations with legal responsibilities in crime prevention and prosecuting, judging or punishing criminal offenders. A number of these organisations feels an increasing pressure of its environment and experiences difficulties in controlling the safety risk. One of these organisations, is the police force. However, dramatic events in the 80-90ties have raised questions about the effectiveness, efficiency and integrity of the police apparatus. Not surprisingly, a number of plans aiming at a total transformation of the formal police organisation have been proposed by different policy makers. In December, 7 1998, the Belgian legislator approved a law which set the outlines of organiational structuresfor the three, (until then) existing, autonomous police organisations. These three organisations were completely abolished and replaced by one formal police organisation with two separate, and to a certain degree independently operating, functional levels (federal vs. local police). Considering the central role the police apparatus plays in modern, nation-state societies, and in view of the total transformation that took place in Belgium since the introduction of the federal and local police structure, the time and means are there to explore the theoretical question how traditional, bureaucratic organisations interact with their environment. Modern organisation concepts as the\xa0'flexible' or\xa0'learning' firm take advantages of advancements in systems theory, where there isa shift in treating organisations as open systems (as opposed to closedsystem), thereby emphasizing that systems have to interact with environment in order to be successful.\xa0The research project thus aims at unravelling the organisational structure of the\xa0'new' Belgian policeapparatus and comparing it to concepts of modern organisational theories. In a first phase, a generic descritpion will be offered which will allow the comparison of modern to traditional,\xa0'tayloristic' organisations. In a second phase, this conceptual scheme will be applied to the Belgian police force. Data wil lbe gathered via a structures questionnaire derived from the conceptual scheme. Qualitative techniques, i.e. faceto face interviews, will be used to construct, pilot and finalize this survey. A representative, large N-sample will be drawn from all local police posts. The conceptual model will guide the data analysis. The analysis should make clear whether or not the transformation of the police apparatus embodies a break with traditional organisation structures and isinspired by modern organisation concepts.\xa0\xa0\xa0

  • Program : Aspiranten

  • Sociology
  • Sociology of labour, sociology of enterprise

column12:
(In)Finitude in Kant, Cassirer, Heidegger and L\xe9vinas. (3H100433)
Promotor :
  • person Desmond William (+) - Centre for Metaphysics, Philosophy of Religion and Philosophy of Culture (+)
Co-promotor(s)
  • personde Boer Karin (+) - Centre for Metaphysics, Philosophy of Religion and Philosophy of Culture (+)
Duration :
01/10/2010 - 30/09/2014
Doctorandus :
Truwant Simon - Doctoral Programme in Philosophy (Leuven) - Institute of Philosophy
Project summary :

In my doctoral dissertation I want to uncover the theme of the human (in)finitude, taking as a point of departure the Davos-debate (1929). Cassirer\xa0and Heidegger had a discussion there concerning the right interpretation of Kant’s Kritik\xa0der reinen Vernunft, and more broadlyof the entire\xa0philosophy of this Enlightenment thinker. At stake was\xa0the interpretation of the Kantian subject as being a finite (Heidegger) oran infinite (Cassirer) subject. Step by step, I want to\xa0show 1) the philosophical consequences of the different views and 2)\xa0how this difference\xa0in opinions has\xa0been of a big\xa0importance\xa0for\xa0the look of the\xa0entire twentieth century philosophy. The first part thus exists in investigating and comparing the\xa0visions of three eminent\xa0thinkers in the history of philosophy on the\xa0theme of the human (in)finitude. In\xa0the\xa0second partI will try to\xa0show\xa0that\xa0this topic can\xa0also\xa0be useful for the understanding of a wavering\xa0between modern\xa0and\xa0postmodern thinking\xa0that\xa0occurs in contemporary metaphysics. I will do this\xa0by turning to the disputebetween Levinas and Heidegger, which I believe\xa0shows extensive similarities with the debate between Cassirer\xa0and Heidegger.

Financing :
  • Funder : FWO (Fonds Wetenschappelijk Onderzoek)
  • Program : Aspiranten
Discipline(s) :
  • Systematic philosophy, ethics, aesthetics, metaphysics, epistemology, ideology
  • History of philosophy

column6:
(In)Finitude in Kant, Cassirer, Heidegger and L\xe9vinas. (3H100433)
Promotor :
  • person Desmond William (+) - Centre for Metaphysics, Philosophy of Religion and Philosophy of Culture (+)
Co-promotor(s)
  • personde Boer Karin (+) - Centre for Metaphysics, Philosophy of Religion and Philosophy of Culture (+)
Duration :
01/10/2010 - 30/09/2014
Doctorandus :
Truwant Simon - Doctoral Programme in Philosophy (Leuven) - Institute of Philosophy
Project summary :

In my doctoral dissertation I want to uncover the theme of the human (in)finitude, taking as a point of departure the Davos-debate (1929). Cassirer\xa0and Heidegger had a discussion there concerning the right interpretation of Kant’s Kritik\xa0der reinen Vernunft, and more broadlyof the entire\xa0philosophy of this Enlightenment thinker. At stake was\xa0the interpretation of the Kantian subject as being a finite (Heidegger) oran infinite (Cassirer) subject. Step by step, I want to\xa0show 1) the philosophical consequences of the different views and 2)\xa0how this difference\xa0in opinions has\xa0been of a big\xa0importance\xa0for\xa0the look of the\xa0entire twentieth century philosophy. The first part thus exists in investigating and comparing the\xa0visions of three eminent\xa0thinkers in the history of philosophy on the\xa0theme of the human (in)finitude. In\xa0the\xa0second partI will try to\xa0show\xa0that\xa0this topic can\xa0also\xa0be useful for the understanding of a wavering\xa0between modern\xa0and\xa0postmodern thinking\xa0that\xa0occurs in contemporary metaphysics. I will do this\xa0by turning to the disputebetween Levinas and Heidegger, which I believe\xa0shows extensive similarities with the debate between Cassirer\xa0and Heidegger.

Financing :
  • Funder : FWO (Fonds Wetenschappelijk Onderzoek)
  • Program : Aspiranten
Discipline(s) :
  • Systematic philosophy, ethics, aesthetics, metaphysics, epistemology, ideology
  • History of philosophy
column9:
(Organisation and Management of Regulation (3H070705)
Promotor :
  • person Verhoest Koen (+) - Public Governance Institute (+)
Duration :
01/10/2007 - 25/06/2012
Doctorandus :
Rommel Jan - Doctoral Programme in Social Sciences (Leuven) - Faculty of Social Sciences
PhD defence date :

25/06/2012

PhD defence file :
http://www.kuleuven.be/doctoraatsverdediging/fiches/3H07/3H070705.htm
Phd Full text :
https://lirias.kuleuven.be/handle/123456789/349740
Project summary :
Regulation is an important task for governments and is frequently used to steer both economic and social activities. In recent years, the literature has described the rise of the ‘regulatory state’, which uses a particular set of instruments (e.g. licensing, inspections) to regulate private actors. The tasks are often allocated to newly created organisations that are placed at arm’s length of the minister (e.g. sectoral regulators in liberalized sectors such as energy, telecommunications, post). Such proliferation of the number of regulators has been said to lead to fragmentation, so that a single organisation no longer has full authority over a particular sector. Instead, sectors are regulated by entire ‘institutional constellations’:\xa0 networks of regulators in different sectors, on different governmental levels and with different regulatory mandates. Each of these bodies has at best a partial authority over a sector. This doctoral research aims two answer two research questions. First,how do these institutional constellations look like? To answer this question, a mapping of regulatory bodies is performed to shed a light on the core characteristics of regulators (e.g. amount of autonomy, extent offragmentation, tasks,…). The second research question is: what is the effect of such constellations on individual regulators? By performing comparative case studies the research explores whether the proliferation and fragmentation may hollow out the factual autonomy of regulators.\xa0
Discipline(s) :
  • Sociology of labour, sociology of enterprise
column12:
(Re-)Organising the state's monopoly on violence: research on the organization, effectiveness and efficiency of the police force by means of an 'overall design'. (3H050458)
Promotor :
  • person Van Hootegem Geert (+) - Centre for Sociological Research (+)
Duration :
01/10/2005 - 30/09/2010
Doctorandus :
Van Beek Gert - Doctoral Programme in Social Sciences (Leuven) - Faculty of Social Sciences
Project summary :
In their observations and descriptions of modern society, contemporary sociologists consistently stress the importance of a number of political, economic, cultural, technological and ideological changes taking placein the context of\xa0'modernity'. Some scholars have characterised this modern society as a\xa0'world risk society' which is dominated by attempts to manage and control\xa0'new' risks, stemming (as side-effects) from modernity itself. One of these risk relates to the problem of (un) safety and (in)security, which can be framed and (partially) explained in the context of the risk society. Some\xa0scholars have consideredcriminality and fear of crime as a specific (social-political) risk forwhich citizens hold the official authorities accountable. In an attemptto manage and minimize this safety risk, modern nation states have designed formal organisations with legal responsibilities in crime prevention and prosecuting, judging or punishing criminal offenders. A number of these organisations feels an increasing pressure of its environment and experiences difficulties in controlling the safety risk. One of these organisations, is the police force. However, dramatic events in the 80-90ties have raised questions about the effectiveness, efficiency and integrity of the police apparatus. Not surprisingly, a number of plans aiming at a total transformation of the formal police organisation have been proposed by different policy makers. In December, 7 1998, the Belgian legislator approved a law which set the outlines of organiational structuresfor the three, (until then) existing, autonomous police organisations. These three organisations were completely abolished and replaced by one formal police organisation with two separate, and to a certain degree independently operating, functional levels (federal vs. local police). Considering the central role the police apparatus plays in modern, nation-state societies, and in view of the total transformation that took place in Belgium since the introduction of the federal and local police structure, the time and means are there to explore the theoretical question how traditional, bureaucratic organisations interact with their environment. Modern organisation concepts as the\xa0'flexible' or\xa0'learning' firm take advantages of advancements in systems theory, where there isa shift in treating organisations as open systems (as opposed to closedsystem), thereby emphasizing that systems have to interact with environment in order to be successful.\xa0The research project thus aims at unravelling the organisational structure of the\xa0'new' Belgian policeapparatus and comparing it to concepts of modern organisational theories. In a first phase, a generic descritpion will be offered which will allow the comparison of modern to traditional,\xa0'tayloristic' organisations. In a second phase, this conceptual scheme will be applied to the Belgian police force. Data wil lbe gathered via a structures questionnaire derived from the conceptual scheme. Qualitative techniques, i.e. faceto face interviews, will be used to construct, pilot and finalize this survey. A representative, large N-sample will be drawn from all local police posts. The conceptual model will guide the data analysis. The analysis should make clear whether or not the transformation of the police apparatus embodies a break with traditional organisation structures and isinspired by modern organisation concepts.\xa0\xa0\xa0
Financing :
  • Funder : FWO (Fonds Wetenschappelijk Onderzoek)
  • Program : Aspiranten
Discipline(s) :
  • Criminology
  • Organizational science
  • Sociology
  • Sociology of labour, sociology of enterprise

In my doctoral dissertation I want to uncover the theme of the human (in)finitude, taking as a point of departure the Davos-debate (1929). Cassirer\xa0and Heidegger had a discussion there concerning the right interpretation of Kant’s Kritik\xa0der reinen Vernunft, and more broadlyof the entire\xa0philosophy of this Enlightenment thinker. At stake was\xa0the interpretation of the Kantian subject as being a finite (Heidegger) oran infinite (Cassirer) subject. Step by step, I want to\xa0show 1) the philosophical consequences of the different views and 2)\xa0how this difference\xa0in opinions has\xa0been of a big\xa0importance\xa0for\xa0the look of the\xa0entire twentieth century philosophy. The first part thus exists in investigating and comparing the\xa0visions of three eminent\xa0thinkers in the history of philosophy on the\xa0theme of the human (in)finitude. In\xa0the\xa0second partI will try to\xa0show\xa0that\xa0this topic can\xa0also\xa0be useful for the understanding of a wavering\xa0between modern\xa0and\xa0postmodern thinking\xa0that\xa0occurs in contemporary metaphysics. I will do this\xa0by turning to the disputebetween Levinas and Heidegger, which I believe\xa0shows extensive similarities with the debate between Cassirer\xa0and Heidegger.

column12:
(Organisation and Management of Regulation (3H070705)
Promotor :
  • person Verhoest Koen (+) - Public Governance Institute (+)
Duration :
01/10/2007 - 25/06/2012
Doctorandus :
Rommel Jan - Doctoral Programme in Social Sciences (Leuven) - Faculty of Social Sciences
PhD defence date :

25/06/2012

PhD defence file :
http://www.kuleuven.be/doctoraatsverdediging/fiches/3H07/3H070705.htm
Phd Full text :
https://lirias.kuleuven.be/handle/123456789/349740
Project summary :
Regulation is an important task for governments and is frequently used to steer both economic and social activities. In recent years, the literature has described the rise of the ‘regulatory state’, which uses a particular set of instruments (e.g. licensing, inspections) to regulate private actors. The tasks are often allocated to newly created organisations that are placed at arm’s length of the minister (e.g. sectoral regulators in liberalized sectors such as energy, telecommunications, post). Such proliferation of the number of regulators has been said to lead to fragmentation, so that a single organisation no longer has full authority over a particular sector. Instead, sectors are regulated by entire ‘institutional constellations’:\xa0 networks of regulators in different sectors, on different governmental levels and with different regulatory mandates. Each of these bodies has at best a partial authority over a sector. This doctoral research aims two answer two research questions. First,how do these institutional constellations look like? To answer this question, a mapping of regulatory bodies is performed to shed a light on the core characteristics of regulators (e.g. amount of autonomy, extent offragmentation, tasks,…). The second research question is: what is the effect of such constellations on individual regulators? By performing comparative case studies the research explores whether the proliferation and fragmentation may hollow out the factual autonomy of regulators.\xa0
Discipline(s) :
  • Sociology of labour, sociology of enterprise

column9:
(Re-)Organising the state's monopoly on violence: research on the organization, effectiveness and efficiency of the police force by means of an 'overall design'. (3H050458)
Promotor :
  • person Van Hootegem Geert (+) - Centre for Sociological Research (+)
Duration :
01/10/2005 - 30/09/2010
Doctorandus :
Van Beek Gert - Doctoral Programme in Social Sciences (Leuven) - Faculty of Social Sciences
Project summary :
In their observations and descriptions of modern society, contemporary sociologists consistently stress the importance of a number of political, economic, cultural, technological and ideological changes taking placein the context of\xa0'modernity'. Some scholars have characterised this modern society as a\xa0'world risk society' which is dominated by attempts to manage and control\xa0'new' risks, stemming (as side-effects) from modernity itself. One of these risk relates to the problem of (un) safety and (in)security, which can be framed and (partially) explained in the context of the risk society. Some\xa0scholars have consideredcriminality and fear of crime as a specific (social-political) risk forwhich citizens hold the official authorities accountable. In an attemptto manage and minimize this safety risk, modern nation states have designed formal organisations with legal responsibilities in crime prevention and prosecuting, judging or punishing criminal offenders. A number of these organisations feels an increasing pressure of its environment and experiences difficulties in controlling the safety risk. One of these organisations, is the police force. However, dramatic events in the 80-90ties have raised questions about the effectiveness, efficiency and integrity of the police apparatus. Not surprisingly, a number of plans aiming at a total transformation of the formal police organisation have been proposed by different policy makers. In December, 7 1998, the Belgian legislator approved a law which set the outlines of organiational structuresfor the three, (until then) existing, autonomous police organisations. These three organisations were completely abolished and replaced by one formal police organisation with two separate, and to a certain degree independently operating, functional levels (federal vs. local police). Considering the central role the police apparatus plays in modern, nation-state societies, and in view of the total transformation that took place in Belgium since the introduction of the federal and local police structure, the time and means are there to explore the theoretical question how traditional, bureaucratic organisations interact with their environment. Modern organisation concepts as the\xa0'flexible' or\xa0'learning' firm take advantages of advancements in systems theory, where there isa shift in treating organisations as open systems (as opposed to closedsystem), thereby emphasizing that systems have to interact with environment in order to be successful.\xa0The research project thus aims at unravelling the organisational structure of the\xa0'new' Belgian policeapparatus and comparing it to concepts of modern organisational theories. In a first phase, a generic descritpion will be offered which will allow the comparison of modern to traditional,\xa0'tayloristic' organisations. In a second phase, this conceptual scheme will be applied to the Belgian police force. Data wil lbe gathered via a structures questionnaire derived from the conceptual scheme. Qualitative techniques, i.e. faceto face interviews, will be used to construct, pilot and finalize this survey. A representative, large N-sample will be drawn from all local police posts. The conceptual model will guide the data analysis. The analysis should make clear whether or not the transformation of the police apparatus embodies a break with traditional organisation structures and isinspired by modern organisation concepts.\xa0\xa0\xa0

column6:
(Organisation and Management of Regulation (3H070705)
Promotor :
  • person Verhoest Koen (+) - Public Governance Institute (+)
Duration :
01/10/2007 - 25/06/2012
Doctorandus :
Rommel Jan - Doctoral Programme in Social Sciences (Leuven) - Faculty of Social Sciences
PhD defence date :

25/06/2012

PhD defence file :
http://www.kuleuven.be/doctoraatsverdediging/fiches/3H07/3H070705.htm
Phd Full text :
https://lirias.kuleuven.be/handle/123456789/349740
Project summary :
Regulation is an important task for governments and is frequently used to steer both economic and social activities. In recent years, the literature has described the rise of the ‘regulatory state’, which uses a particular set of instruments (e.g. licensing, inspections) to regulate private actors. The tasks are often allocated to newly created organisations that are placed at arm’s length of the minister (e.g. sectoral regulators in liberalized sectors such as energy, telecommunications, post). Such proliferation of the number of regulators has been said to lead to fragmentation, so that a single organisation no longer has full authority over a particular sector. Instead, sectors are regulated by entire ‘institutional constellations’:\xa0 networks of regulators in different sectors, on different governmental levels and with different regulatory mandates. Each of these bodies has at best a partial authority over a sector. This doctoral research aims two answer two research questions. First,how do these institutional constellations look like? To answer this question, a mapping of regulatory bodies is performed to shed a light on the core characteristics of regulators (e.g. amount of autonomy, extent offragmentation, tasks,…). The second research question is: what is the effect of such constellations on individual regulators? By performing comparative case studies the research explores whether the proliferation and fragmentation may hollow out the factual autonomy of regulators.\xa0
Discipline(s) :
  • Sociology of labour, sociology of enterprise
column9:
(In)Finitude in Kant, Cassirer, Heidegger and L\xe9vinas. (3H100433)
Promotor :
  • person Desmond William (+) - Centre for Metaphysics, Philosophy of Religion and Philosophy of Culture (+)
Co-promotor(s)
  • personde Boer Karin (+) - Centre for Metaphysics, Philosophy of Religion and Philosophy of Culture (+)
Duration :
01/10/2010 - 30/09/2014
Doctorandus :
Truwant Simon - Doctoral Programme in Philosophy (Leuven) - Institute of Philosophy
Project summary :

In my doctoral dissertation I want to uncover the theme of the human (in)finitude, taking as a point of departure the Davos-debate (1929). Cassirer\xa0and Heidegger had a discussion there concerning the right interpretation of Kant’s Kritik\xa0der reinen Vernunft, and more broadlyof the entire\xa0philosophy of this Enlightenment thinker. At stake was\xa0the interpretation of the Kantian subject as being a finite (Heidegger) oran infinite (Cassirer) subject. Step by step, I want to\xa0show 1) the philosophical consequences of the different views and 2)\xa0how this difference\xa0in opinions has\xa0been of a big\xa0importance\xa0for\xa0the look of the\xa0entire twentieth century philosophy. The first part thus exists in investigating and comparing the\xa0visions of three eminent\xa0thinkers in the history of philosophy on the\xa0theme of the human (in)finitude. In\xa0the\xa0second partI will try to\xa0show\xa0that\xa0this topic can\xa0also\xa0be useful for the understanding of a wavering\xa0between modern\xa0and\xa0postmodern thinking\xa0that\xa0occurs in contemporary metaphysics. I will do this\xa0by turning to the disputebetween Levinas and Heidegger, which I believe\xa0shows extensive similarities with the debate between Cassirer\xa0and Heidegger.

Financing :
  • Funder : FWO (Fonds Wetenschappelijk Onderzoek)
  • Program : Aspiranten
Discipline(s) :
  • Systematic philosophy, ethics, aesthetics, metaphysics, epistemology, ideology
  • History of philosophy

column9:
(In)Finitude in Kant, Cassirer, Heidegger and L\xe9vinas. (3H100433)
Promotor :
  • person Desmond William (+) - Centre for Metaphysics, Philosophy of Religion and Philosophy of Culture (+)
Co-promotor(s)
  • personde Boer Karin (+) - Centre for Metaphysics, Philosophy of Religion and Philosophy of Culture (+)
Duration :
01/10/2010 - 30/09/2014
Doctorandus :
Truwant Simon - Doctoral Programme in Philosophy (Leuven) - Institute of Philosophy
Project summary :

In my doctoral dissertation I want to uncover the theme of the human (in)finitude, taking as a point of departure the Davos-debate (1929). Cassirer\xa0and Heidegger had a discussion there concerning the right interpretation of Kant’s Kritik\xa0der reinen Vernunft, and more broadlyof the entire\xa0philosophy of this Enlightenment thinker. At stake was\xa0the interpretation of the Kantian subject as being a finite (Heidegger) oran infinite (Cassirer) subject. Step by step, I want to\xa0show 1) the philosophical consequences of the different views and 2)\xa0how this difference\xa0in opinions has\xa0been of a big\xa0importance\xa0for\xa0the look of the\xa0entire twentieth century philosophy. The first part thus exists in investigating and comparing the\xa0visions of three eminent\xa0thinkers in the history of philosophy on the\xa0theme of the human (in)finitude. In\xa0the\xa0second partI will try to\xa0show\xa0that\xa0this topic can\xa0also\xa0be useful for the understanding of a wavering\xa0between modern\xa0and\xa0postmodern thinking\xa0that\xa0occurs in contemporary metaphysics. I will do this\xa0by turning to the disputebetween Levinas and Heidegger, which I believe\xa0shows extensive similarities with the debate between Cassirer\xa0and Heidegger.

Financing :
  • Funder : FWO (Fonds Wetenschappelijk Onderzoek)
  • Program : Aspiranten
Discipline(s) :
  • Systematic philosophy, ethics, aesthetics, metaphysics, epistemology, ideology
  • History of philosophy
column12:
(Organisation and Management of Regulation (3H070705)
Promotor :
  • person Verhoest Koen (+) - Public Governance Institute (+)
Duration :
01/10/2007 - 25/06/2012
Doctorandus :
Rommel Jan - Doctoral Programme in Social Sciences (Leuven) - Faculty of Social Sciences
PhD defence date :

25/06/2012

PhD defence file :
http://www.kuleuven.be/doctoraatsverdediging/fiches/3H07/3H070705.htm
Phd Full text :
https://lirias.kuleuven.be/handle/123456789/349740
Project summary :
Regulation is an important task for governments and is frequently used to steer both economic and social activities. In recent years, the literature has described the rise of the ‘regulatory state’, which uses a particular set of instruments (e.g. licensing, inspections) to regulate private actors. The tasks are often allocated to newly created organisations that are placed at arm’s length of the minister (e.g. sectoral regulators in liberalized sectors such as energy, telecommunications, post). Such proliferation of the number of regulators has been said to lead to fragmentation, so that a single organisation no longer has full authority over a particular sector. Instead, sectors are regulated by entire ‘institutional constellations’:\xa0 networks of regulators in different sectors, on different governmental levels and with different regulatory mandates. Each of these bodies has at best a partial authority over a sector. This doctoral research aims two answer two research questions. First,how do these institutional constellations look like? To answer this question, a mapping of regulatory bodies is performed to shed a light on the core characteristics of regulators (e.g. amount of autonomy, extent offragmentation, tasks,…). The second research question is: what is the effect of such constellations on individual regulators? By performing comparative case studies the research explores whether the proliferation and fragmentation may hollow out the factual autonomy of regulators.\xa0
Discipline(s) :
  • Sociology of labour, sociology of enterprise
